key_title: Key to the species of Convolvulus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Convolvulaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Bindweeds (Convolvulus L.: Convolvulaceae) in Victoria
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (2012). Bindweeds (Convolvulus L.: Convolvulaceae) in Victoria. In: Victorian Naturalist 129, pp. 10-19. Field Naturalist Club of Victoria, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves hastate, sagittate, oblong or digitate, but not developing a distinct narrow (<2 mm wide) central/terminal lobe more than 5 times longer than the basal lobes (when present); fruiting pedicels straight or recurved
Leaves with a distinct, narrow central lobe more than 5 times longer than short basal lobes, 2 mm wide or less; fruiting pedicels distinctly recurved
Sepals to 4 mm long, with a rounded to truncate, emarginate apex
Sepals 4–7 mm long, rarely shorter, with an acute to rounded, apiculate apex
Petals 15–30 mm long; sepals 3–4 mm long; leaves glabrous or with a few weakly erect hairs; vigorous weed often of disturbed or degraded sites
Petals 5–10 mm long; sepals usually <3 mm long; leaves moderately to sparsely hairy with appressed hairs; native to far north-west Victoria
Mid-stem leaves more or less ovate in outline, margins crenate or serrate, basal lobes usually not prominent, sericeous; hairs more or less appressed, commonly >0.5 mm long
Mid-stem leaves with a distinct central/terminal lobe, margins not crenate or serrate, basal lobes much-divided or auriculate and toothed, not sericeous; hairs usually <0.5 mm long
Leaf margins entire throughout the plant (ignoring short basal lobes if present)
Leaf margins, at least near base of plant, distinctly toothed or lobed

Pedicel recurved in fruit; capsule globose, to 5.5 mm long; seeds to 3.5 mm long, faces with fine pattern of low irregular tubercles; petals to 10 mm long; sepals more or less glabrous to sparsely hairy

Pedicel straight or sinuate in fruit; capsule globose to globose-ovoid, 5.5–8.5 mm long; seeds 3–4.8 mm long, faces with both tubercles and irregular ridges; petals 8–12 mm long; sepals moderately to densely hairy
Corolla with petals <9 mm long; seeds tuberculate; far north-west Victoria only
Corolla with petals >9 mm long; seeds reticulate, tuberculate or smooth; east, north-central or west Victoria but rarely far north-west
Fruiting pedicel more or less straight to sinuate, but not distinctly recurved
Fruiting pedicel recurved

Fruiting pedicels straight or sinuate; flowers 1–3 per axil; leaves shallowly lobed only, more or less glabrous, at least above; stems ribbed to narrowly winged; known with certainty only from limestone areas of Gippsland
Fruiting pedicels distinctly recurved; flowers usually 1 (rarely 2) per axil; at least lower leaves deeply and distinctly lobed, usually distinctly hairy; stems terete
Mid-stem leaves more or less digitate with basal/ascending lobes usually at least half the length of the terminal lobe; northern and western Victoria
Mid-stem leaves more or less linear, if ever somewhat digitate the central lobe usually more than twice as long as basal lobes; widespread
Corolla <9 mm long
Corolla >9 mm long
Sepals more or less glabrous to sparsely hairy; fruiting pedicel 2–12 mm long; seeds densely and fairly evenly tuberculate, lacking ridges, wingless; northern plains and drier eastern ranges
Sepals moderately to densely hairy; fruiting pedicel 3–6 mm long; seeds patterned by irregular tubercles and short ridges with an irregular marginal wing; far north-west Victoria only
Corolla to 10 mm long; seeds fairly evenly tuberculate; peduncle and stems usually narrowly winged or ribbed; northern plains and drier eastern ranges
Corolla to 25 mm long; seeds with low irregular ridges, or virtually smooth with a narrow marginal ridge or wing; peduncles and stems terete; widespread
